##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Hyperweb Server Documentation
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Hyperweb Server Documentation

Background

The Hyperweb Server provides access to the Chimera 2.0 hyperwebs stored on a Chimera website. The Hyperweb Server's chief responsibility is the maintenance of a Chimera 2.0 hyperweb's persistence and consistency. In addition, it communicates hypermedia information (via its API) to Chimera Servers which connect to it on behalf of their clients.

As a system administration tool, the Hyperweb Server provides operations to export and import Chimera hyperwebs. These hyperwebs can be exported or imported individually or as a set. In addition, for each Chimera website, the hyperweb server maintains a database that tracks information about the viewers, objects, and views referenced by the anchors and links in the website's hyperwebs. The information in this database is available globally across all of the hyperwebs at a particular Chimera website. This database is known as the VOV (for Viewers, Objects, and Views) and it can be imported and exported as well.

User-Interface

The Hyperweb Server's user-interface is contained within a single window that localizes its operations and status information. Each Menu and Tab of the user-interface is explained through the links below.

Menus

File
     Export
     Import
     Look-and-Feel


Tabs

Hyperwebs
     Documentation
     Hyperweb Server Log
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://ftp.ics.uci.edu/pub/chimera/docs/chimeraserver/index.html
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Chimera Server Documentation
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Chimera Server Documentation

Background

The Chimera Server is the user's window into the Chimera world. The Chimera Server provides operations to connect to a Chimera 2.0 website and allow hypermedia-enabled clients to access Chimera's hypermedia services.

There is an analogy between the Chimera Server's relationship with Chimera websites and a Web browser's relationship with WWW sites. Just as a user would use a URL to specify interest in a particular WWW site, a user can select among Chimera 2.0 websites and the hyperwebs stored there. To continue the analogy, once the Web browser has downloaded the requested URL, the user has access to hypermedia services such as the ability to follow HTML links. In the same manner, once the user has selected a Chimera hyperweb, all Chimera-aware clients can provide the user with hypermedia services such as the ability to follow Chimera links.

The Chimera Server also provides Chimera with a proxy in the user's environment which allows it to communicate with the user when it needs more information or to report an error. In addition, the user is able to configure the behavior of Chimera and to create and manipulate Chimera links.

Connecting to a Chimera Website

An example of accessing a Chimera website using the Chimera Server is available.

User-Interface

The Chimera Server's user-interface is contained within a single window that localizes its operations and status information. Each Menu and Tab of the user-interface is explained through the links below.

Menus

File
      Look-and-Feel


Tabs

Servers
      Webs
      Links
      Documentation
      Chimera Server Log
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://ftp.ics.uci.edu/pub/chimera/docs/hyperwebmanager/index.html
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Hyperweb Manager Documentation
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Hyperweb Manager Documentation

Background

The Hyperweb Manager is a system administration tool for the
management of Chimera 2.0 hyperwebs.  In addition, it tracks the
location of other Chimera 2.0 servers (such as the Hyperweb Server and
the Applet Server) running on the Hyperweb Manager's website.

The Hyperweb Manager provides operations to manipulate Chimera 2.0
hyperwebs. For instance, a user can use the Hyperweb Manager to create a
new hyperweb or delete an old one. In addition, the user can determine
if a Hyperweb Server is active for the website and connect or disconnect
one if required. Finally, a user can monitor a log of the Hyperweb
Manager's interactions with other Chimera 2.0 servers.

User-Interface

The Hyperweb Manager's user-interface is contained within a single
window that localizes its operations and status information. Each Menu
and Tab of the user-interface is explained through the links below.

Menus

File
     Look-and-Feel


Tabs

Hyperwebs
     Hyperweb Server Info
     Documentation
     Hyperweb Manager Log
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://ftp.ics.uci.edu/pub/chimera/docs/appletserver/index.html
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Applet Server Documentation
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Applet Server Documentation

Background

The Applet Server allow Java applets to partcipate as full Chimera clients.  
Since applets can only communicate with the website where they 
were down-loaded from, the Applet Server allows for the Applet to 
interact as if it were a Chimera client communicating through a Chimera
Server in the user's environment.  This means that the Applets can act as 
clients in the user's environment dispite the fact that they actually can
only act through the Chimera website.  

Note:  At this time, the Applet Server automatically comes up 
when the Hyperweb Manager is started.  The Applet Server will automatically 
start whenever it is deactivated by the Quit command in the
File menu, and there is a Hyperweb Manager running at
the Chimera website.  

Note:  An Applet Server is started for each user using a 
Chimera enabled applet.  

User-Interface

 The Applet Server's user-interface is contained within a 
window that allows its status to be visible.  There 
are no special operations available with the Applet Server.  

Menus

File
	Look-and-Feel


Tabs

Documentation
	Applet Server Log

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld043.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Properties:
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Properties: Value is well-formed XML 
 The value of a property is a well-formed XML (eXtensible Markup Language) fragment

WebDAV also requires use of XML Namespaces
Benefits:

supports “plug-and-play” of W3C RDF work
i18n support: XML supports ISO 10646 encoding of characters
property contents are structured values
extensibility: namespaces allow mix of elements in properties

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
XML-LANG: Markup Types
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
XML-LANG: Markup Types 
 Elements - start-tags, end-tags, empty tags

<joke>Take my XML. Please.<applause/></joke> 
Attributes - name-value pairs in tags

<warning class=“emergency”>
Entity References - special chars, macros, external elements

" or &4k-logo;
Comments - not passed along to application

<!-- Not allowed two dashes before end of comment. -->
Processing Instructions - passed along to application

<?pi-target-name pi-data?>
CDATA Sections - parser ignores markup for Character Data

 *p = &q; b = (i <= 3);

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
XLink: Advanced
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
XLink: Advanced 
 Extended links - can be multidirectional, need not live in the resources they point, link groups

<related-term-group>Hamlet <related-term HREF=“Othello.xml”/><related-term HREF=“KingLear.xml”/><related-term HREF=“Macbeth.xml”/></related-term-group>
<!ELEMENT related-term-group (#PCDATA | related-term)* ><!ATTLIST related-term-group     XML-LINK  CDATA  #FIXED  “EXTENDED”     INLINE  CDATA  #FIXED  “TRUE”     CONTENT-ROLE  CDATA  #FIXED  “RT” … >
Extended Pointers - locate resource by traversing the element tree of its containing document 

XPointers allow links without modifying the containing document

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
World-Wide Markup Language
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
World-Wide Markup Language 
 “The HyperText Markup Language is an SGML format.”  [Tim Berners-Lee, 1991, “About HTML”]

Standard, Open Document Formats since the 1960s (GCA’s GenCode, IBM’s GML)

SGML [ISO 8879:1986] can prove the validity of any document using standardized DTDs, complex structuring, extensions

In 1990, Berners-Lee picked tags from a sample SGML DTD and added a “killer feature”: links



The World-Wide HTML tagset is limited to the 80/20 rule

XML allows Community-Wide Markup Languages,combining SGML’s power with HTML’s simplicity


 

 Previous slide  Next slide  Back to first slide  View graphic version
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld021.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
XSL: “Behavior Sheets”
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
XSL: “Behavior Sheets” 
 CSS1 - formatting rules in terms of element names, Ids, …

XSL - based on DSSSL (ISO/IEC 10179:1996)

Formatting specification derived from active style sheets
With XML doc structure, create flow objects (paragraphs, tables, ...) with characteristics (font-name, font-size, …)
Merging, flow object tree determines document layout
Can calculate tables-of-contents, indexes, other scripts
Scheme - core expression (math) language in XS

Construction rules declare element style

font-size: 18pt, first-line-start-indent: 20pt, quadding: left
Typically, formatting declared as functions

(element CODE (UNDERLINED-PHRASE))

##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld002.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
“The next phase of the Web”
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
“The next phase of the Web” 
 With the dramatic flood of rich material of all kinds onto the Web in the 1990s, the first part of the dream is largely realized, although still very few people in practice have access to intuitive hypertext creation tools. The second part has yet to happen, but there are signs and plans which make us confident. The great need for information about information, to help us categorize, sort, pay for, own information is driving the design of languages for the web designed for processing by machines, rather than people.The web of human-readable document is being merged with a web of machine-understandable data. The potential of the mixture of humans and machines working together and communicating through the web could be immense. 

W3C Director Tim Berners-Lee, May 1998

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Metadata Recording Infrastructure
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Metadata Recording Infrastructure 
 Metadata support

Properties. (name, value) pairs can be created, modified, deleted, and read on Web resources.
Consistency of properties can be maintained by the server or the client
Property values are well-formed Extensible Markup Language (XML)
Infrastructure for how to record information about Web data

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Scenario: Web Portfolio Manager
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Scenario: Web Portfolio Manager 
 Latency: Observation = ~0 (triggered by update 15 mins after stock prices change), Delivery = HTTP connection

Intermediation: Portfolio Server computes total portfolio value before sending information to the client

Initiator: Portfolio Server receives “pushed” quotes from Stock Server, does recalculation, then initiates with client

Delivery Constraints: Reliable Connection

Notification Management:

Client subscription request enumerates current holdings

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
XML-LANG: DTDs (2/2)
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
XML-LANG: DTDs (2/2) 
 Attribute Declarations - name, type, default

Attribute types: CDATA, ID, IDREF/IDREFS, ENTITY/ENTITIES, NMTOKEN/NMTOKENS, a list of names
Default values: #REQUIRED, #IMPLIED, “value”, #FIXED “value”
Entity Declarations - associate name with chunk

Internal entities:  < > & ' "or locally defined: ⋔  <!ENTITY  fork  “4K Consulting”>
External entities: <!ENTITY forkfooter SYSTEM “fork/footer.xml”><!ENTITY pic SYSTEM “http://xent.ics.uci.edu/4k.gif” NDATA GIF87A>
Parameter entities: <!ENTITY %  html.ver “-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0//EN”>
Notation Declarations - external binary data

<!NOTATION GIF87A SYSTEM “GIF”>

Airline Passenger Name Records

Must be manipulated throughout its lifetime
Need stable data format, stable grain of exchange, and common definitions

Security Considerations
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Security Considerations 
 Trust management concerns of messaging apps

Authenticating counterparties, integrity, confidentiality
Trust mgmt issues of subscription maintenance

Subscriber verification and access control
Events, sources, sinks, and roles may be sensitive

Inclusion and exclusion of overlapping groups

Firewall traversal is an administrator’s prerogative

Performance of session vs. message protection

Delegation of rights introduces revocation mgmt

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Network Effects
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Network Effects 
 XML, WebDAV, and ISEN each generate network effects for each other

WebDAV increases the value of XML by linking it to resources
XML increases the value of WebDAV by providing an extensible marshalling syntax
ISEN services increase the value of WebDAV by adding awareness information

Structural HTML:

<CITE&#062XML, Java, and the Future of the Web</CITE> 		<H3>World Wide Web Journal</H3> 		<H4>Jon Bosak</H4><UL>	<LI> 2(4):219-228 		<LI> 1997  	</UL>

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Capturing the State of Distributed Systems in XML
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Capturing the State of Distributed Systems in XML 
 Implications & Applications of XML

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
What is WEBDAV?
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
What is WEBDAV? 
 Working Group on Distributed Authoring and Versioning on the World Wide Web



Goal: To enable distributed web authoring tools to be broadly interoperable.

Home page:

	http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/webdav/

##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld030.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Using WebDAV
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Using WebDAV 
 You have a report to produce

Fire up your favorite word processor & start editing
You decide to bring on another author

Using the same word processor, save to the Web
Start collaboration on the document by editing in-place on the Web
A seamless transition from individual to collaborative work

##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld058.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Notification Protocol Candidates
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Notification Protocol Candidates 
 Create new conventions for existing protocols...

SMTP + List addresses
NNTP + Newsgroups
HTTP + Callbacks
…or invent a new protocol...

(Not based on HTTP) BLIP, SIN, SGAP
(Loosely based on HTTP) SIP, RVP
(HTTP extensions) ENP, SWAP, GENA Base, …
…but don’t hammer away with HTTP alone

draft-iesg-using-http-00.txt

	Implication	Capturing the State of Distributed Systems

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Namespace Management Infrastructure
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Namespace Management Infrastructure 
 Remote name space management:

Copy resources
Move resources
Create and modify (ordered) collections of resources
Add/remove members by-reference
Infrastructure for remotely organizing and viewing collections of Web resources

##------------------URL-------------------------##

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Searching Infrastructure
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Searching Infrastructure 
 Searching a WebDAV repository - DASL:

Search for resources with a given property, or a given property value
Search for a substring inside a resource body
Search scope can be one resource, a collection of resources, a hierarchy of resources, or a whole server
Infrastructure for remote searching

 

 Previous slide  Next slide  Back to first slide  View graphic version
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld019.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
XLink : ‘Real’ Hypertext Links
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
XLink : ‘Real’ Hypertext Links 
 Start with HTML, add HyTime and TEI concepts

Simple links point to a single target resource

<A XML-LINK=“SIMPLE” HREF=“http://www.w3.org/XML”>
URL schemes: ftp, http, file, mailto, telnet, nntp, ...
Links can have roles (machine-processible) and human-readable labels associated with them

Can specify default behavior of a link

SHOW - embed in current context, replace it, or start new one
ACTUATE - user must take action (or not) before dereferencing
Locators - # separates resource name and part id

Connectors - | to navigate to relevant element(s) only


 

 Previous slide  Next slide  Back to first slide  View graphic version
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld010.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Community-Wide Markup Languages
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Community-Wide Markup Languages 
 Community size is inversely proportional to shared context

Millions agree that <B> means bold, but “2/6/98” reflects local culture
XML decentralizes control of specialized markup languages,making it cost-effective to capture community ontologies
HTML is not unilaterally extensible --	new tags potentially have ambiguous syntax, style, and semantics

XML is a strict (but simplified) subset of SGML, offering:

Extensibility -- can define new elements, containers, attribute names
Structure -- a DTD can constrain the information model of a document
Validation -- every document can be validated; also, well-formedness can establish conformance to the structure mandated by the DTD
XML includes extensible linking and style formatting also

“Node content must be left free to evolve.”  [Tim Berners-Lee, 1991, “About Document Formats”]

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Across Time
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Across Time 
 Tensions Create Brittle Data Formats

Inertia, Efficiency, Tools, and Context
Future-Proofing Strategies

Machine-Readable - for parsers & generators
Human-Readable - robustness and simplicity
Self-Descriptive - for extraction and validation
XML as Basis to Execute Strategies

e.g., Capturing Database Schema as DTDs

##------------------URL-------------------------##

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
XML-LANG
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
XML-LANG 
 Self-description with Document Type Definition (DTD):

Structural rules of the document’s markup
External entities, internal entities, non-XML resource entities
Non-Minimization (All Markup is Explicit)

XML Processor - customizable info structures

Most XML users will not know they are using a DTD!
XML-aware software works with custom XML apps without help 
Document Validity = Conforms to DTD

Document well-formedness = structurally sound, but no DTD
Required Markup Declaration (RMD) indicates need for DTD
Well-formedness for delivery format, validity for authoring

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
WebDAV and DASL
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
WebDAV and DASL 
 WebDAV

IETF WebDAV Working Group Home Page	http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/webdav/
WebDAV Flyer	http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/webdav/webdav_flyer.pdf
WebDAV Distributed Authoring Protocol	http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/webdav/protocol/	draft-ietf-webdav-protocol-08.pdf
Requirements for a Distributed Authoring Protocol for the WWW	http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/webdav/requirements/rfc2291.txt
DASL

DASL Home Page	http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/dasl/
Requirements for DAV Searching and Locating	http://egg.microsoft.com/dasl/files/draft-dasl-requirements-00.html

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Taxonomy of Design Decisions
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Taxonomy of Design Decisions 
 Latency

Min and max bounds, for event observation & delivery
Intermediation (end-to-end or relayed)

Initiation (by sources or by sinks)

Delivery Constraints

Guarantees, transport choices, retry policies
Notification Management

Event filtering, aggregating, and queueing
(Un)Subscription, access control, group management

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Web Automation & Collaboration
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Web Automation & Collaboration 
 Automation	XML

Shifting from “screen-scrapers” of presentational data to programmatic access to logical data
Collaboration	DAV

Returning the Web to a read and write medium...
... And adding coordination for group authoring
Notification	ISEN

A better way to observe events affecting Web resources than continuous polling...
...By distributing Web information in both directions
 

 Previous slide  Next slide  Back to first slide  View graphic version
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld004.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Interdependencies
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Interdependencies 
 The enabling technologies for automation and collaboration are interdependent

XML is the key to automation, and is the format of WebDAV properties
WebDAV properties provide metadata storage with Web resources, linking XML to the resources they describe
ISEN provides awareness of activities of collaborators using WebDAV
A collaborator has been added, or a lock has been released

locked

 Previous slide  Next slide  Back to first slide  View graphic version
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld042.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Properties: Naming
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Properties: Naming 
 Properties are (name, value) pairs

Property names are URIs

can be a URL (no registration needed)
can be a URI (register new URI scheme)
Benefits:

Due to ownership of a domain name, URLs provide globally unique names without registration
URLs allow rapid development and deployment of new schemas
Stable, long-lifetime schemas can be named with a URI scheme, which is registered with IANA

 Web Authoring

Property updates
Internet Printing

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Application Use of WebDAV
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Application Use of WebDAV 
 
Client

Server

File… Open

LOCK

Lock resource

PROPFIND

Send properties 

to client

GET

Send resource

contents to client

Edit

PUT

File… Save

Exit

UNLOCK

Save new contents

Unlock resource

##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld037.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Write Lock
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Write Lock 
 Write lock is the only lock access type defined in this specification

A write lock prevents a principal without the lock from successfully modifying the state of the resource

Specifically, it prevents execution of PUT, POST, DELETE, MKCOL, PROPPATCH, MOVE, LOCK, UNLOCK
GET, PROPFIND are unaffected by write lock

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld006.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Our Goal: 	Remote, Collaborative
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Our Goal: 	Remote, Collaborative 			Software Engineering 
 Automation and collaboration is a major building block for software engineering via the Web

Collaborative development of software artifacts
XML is a flexible marshalling syntax for remote operations like a remote software build
ISENs inform other software engineers on the status of development artifacts


In turn, Web-based software engineering supports virtual development teams.

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Strawman Definitions
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Strawman Definitions 
 Event notification service

No globally consistent definition or shared model
Notifications

Events, once observed at sources, generate  notifications, which are then delivered to sinks 
Notification messaging

Need an application-layer analogue to datagrams
Notification management mechanisms

Mailing list subscriptions, newsgroup creation, multicast address allocation, publish-and-subscribe, chat spanning tree construction, event coalescing

##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld008.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Origin and Mission of XML
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Origin and Mission of XML 
 XML was designed to provide an easy-to-write, easy-to-interpret, and easy-to-implement subset of SGML.  It was not designed to provide a “one Markup Language fits all” DTD, or a separate DTD for every tag.  It was designed so that certain groups could create their own particular markup languages that meet their needs more quickly, efficiently, and (IMO) logically.  It was designed to put an end once and for all to the tag-soup wars propagated by Microsoft and Netscape.     			Jim Cape, June 3, 1997			posted to comp.infosystems.www.authoring.html

http://www.ics.uci.edu/~irus/css/98/mini-tutorial/tsld031.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
WebDAV: Extending HTTP
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
WebDAV: Extending HTTP 
 WebDAV is a major extension to HTTP

WebDAV adds properties and collections to HTTP resource data model
WebDAV provides facilities for

Properties - list, add, remove
Namespace Operations - move, copy
Overwrite prevention - lock, unlock
Collections - mkcol, hierarchy operations

##------------------URL-------------------------##

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Citation Encodings (2/2)
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Citation Encodings (2/2) 
 Customized XML:

<BIB><TITLE&#062XML, Java, and the Future of the Web</TITLE><JOURNAL>World Wide Web Journal</JOURNAL><AUTHOR> <FIRSTNAME>Jon</FIRSTNAME> <LASTNAME>Bosak</LASTNAME></AUTHOR><VOLUMEɮ</VOLUME> <NUMBERɰ</NUMBER> <YEAR򗶭</YEAR>   <PAGES-228</PAGES> </BIB>
Resource Description Format, using namespaces:

<RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/TR/WD-rdf-syntax#”         xmlns:bib="http://library.org/bibliography-info/”         xmlns:dc="http://oclc.org/DublinCore/RDFSchema"><rdf:Description about=		"http://sunsite.unc.edu/pub/sun-info/standards/xml/why/xmlapps.htm”>   <bib:TITLE> XML, Java, and the Future of the Web </bib:TITLE>   <dc:Creator>Jon Bosak</dc:Creator>   <bib:VOLUMEɮ</bib:VOLUME>  <bib:NUMBERɰ</bib:NUMBER>   <bib:YEAR򗶭</bib:YEAR>   <bib:PAGES-228</bib:PAGES></rdf:Description> </RDF>

##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Critical Problems
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Critical Problems 
 Modeling dynamism

what level of abstraction? what can change?
Analysis and testing

evolution without sacrificing application integrity
impossible to test all system permutations
implies testing after deployment
System deployment

what portion of the system model is deployed?
Triggering evolution

explicitly by end-users, implicitly through monitoring
Runtime support

ArchStudio: Intent
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
ArchStudio: Intent 
  

 Previous slide  Next slide  Back to first slide  View graphic version
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~peymano/dynamic-arch/austin/oreizy/tsld003.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Importance of Open Dynamic Systems
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Importance of Open Dynamic Systems 
 Model existing dynamic systems

operating systems, OLE- and CORBA-based systems
usability, scalability, integration, distribution
Growing number of systems require “continuous availability”

mission- and safety- critical systems
adapt to changing environment, reduce the cost/risk of shutdown and restart
Commercial end-user applications

third-party extensions and plug-ins
end-user customization and extension
 

 Previous slide  Next slide  Back to first slide  View graphic version
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~peymano/dynamic-arch/austin/oreizy/tsld004.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Research at UC Irvine
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Research at UC Irvine 
 Architecture-based approach

conceptual basis for understanding and reasoning about systems
Architectural style impacts dynamism

e.g., benefits of “substrate independence” in C2 style
Connectors

provide a critical abstraction for dynamism
should remain explicit and flexible in implementation
Implementation

ArchStudio tool suite supporting runtime system evolution
 

 Previous slide  Next slide  Back to first slide  View graphic version
##------------------URL-------------------------##
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~peymano/dynamic-arch/austin/oreizy/tsld002.htm
##-----------------TITLE------------------------##
Degrees of Dynamism
##------------------TEXT------------------------##
Degrees of Dynamism 
 Static

complete system behavior described at build time
examples: Wright, UniCON, etc.
Closed dynamic

complete system behavior described at build time
describe changes during design (must predict change)
examples: DARWIN, Rapide
Open dynamic

system behavior may evolve after build time
describe previously unanticipated changes during runtime
examples: C2
